item.title: Gary Marcus
item.description: History will show that single biggest obstacle to accelerating AI in the first half of the 2020s was not chips, data, money, or energy, but groupthink.Dozens of companies spending tens of billions dollars training on essentially the same data producing essentially the same results with the same core issues, over and over. In hindsight it will seem like madness.

item.title: Aslan
item.description: @computingnature Hi Carsen! I went through the paper... the way that you use the method to analyse artificial neural networks is interesting! I might use the method for my own project.

item.title: Carsen Stringer (she/her)
item.description:
Six tips for going public with your lab‚Äôs software: https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-024-03344-y
1) make time for maintenance
2) simplify installation
3) add a GUI or good CLI
4) good documentation
5) use github/git
6) automated testing

Any other tips people have? #SoftwareEngineering #opensource #openscience

item.title: Koen Hufkens, PhD
item.description: @computingnature It must live at least 10 years! Too often software, these days in academia, is an easy way to score another publication, longevity and stability be damned. If you can't support it for 10 years, don't bother IMO. Long-term support, and a vision towards this before you publish and make a lot of noise around it, is required.https://ossforclimate.sustainoss.org/3

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description:
It‚Äôs amazing that a dramatic case of evolution is in your spit, and it helps you eat French fries. Here‚Äôs a gift link to my New York Times column this week on the swift evolution of amylase https://nyti.ms/3C1EmXG?utm_source=carlzimmer&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fridays-elk-french-fries-and-the-evolving-natural For this week‚Äôs email newsletter, I muse about what this research says about the question of whether food is good or bad for us. Another way of asking that question is: do you have one amylase gene, or eleven?
https://buttondown.com/carlzimmer/archive/fridays-elk-french-fries-and-the-evolving-natural/

item.title: Dan Neidle
item.description: It is the year 3000. Council tax applies on all colonised planets based on valuations from 1991. Or we could reform property tax. Thread.

@computingnature

item.title: jonny (good kind)
item.description:
@computingnature
The "simplify installation" one aka "package your code" is so huge. The number of projects I come across that are simply unpackaged or just have a plaintext list of deps and are otherwise a loose bundle of MATLAB or python files are always unfortunate, because they rarely survive longer than the paper announcement. Thinking about how I spent a day repackaging moseq bc someone in our lab was curious about it but couldnt install, and then never got a reply in the issue

item.title: jonny (good kind)
item.description:
@computingnature
These cover a lot of common problems I have with scientific code, one minor one to add is "build more, smaller things" - splitting up a very large monolithic code base into several smaller pieces can work with all the above tips to make the software much more useful over time. Being able to re-use pieces between projects without needing to make future projects direct dependents of humongous prior packages is a huge deal for labs that might make many tools.

item.title: MCDuncanLab
item.description: @DesrochersLab JHU publishes a very comprehensive list of fellowships. It lists whether they are open to no-US citizens but does not list funding rates. They also have a sublist each for neuroscience and cancer.https://research.jhu.edu/rdt/funding-opportunities/postdoctoral/

item.title: Matt Hodgkinson
item.description: "Scientists and those who champion them should never close ranks against empirical challenge and criticism."George Monbiot on how criticism of the framing of CFS/ME as a psychiatric illness was portrayed as abusive to delegitimise patient concerns.https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2024/oct/18/maeve-bothby-oneill-me-chronic-fatigue-syndrome#CFSME #GeorgeMonbiot #ScientificConsensus

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: This rather drives home the point that it will be beyond the means of most people to defend against drones. Drones will also make it difficult (impossible) to catch or even identify the controller. We can look forward to an explosion in the number of assassinations carried out with impunity.https://www.theguardian.com/world/2024/oct/19/netanyahus-house-hit-by-drone-as-israel-and-hezbollah-trade-blows-in-lebanon

item.title: Dean Burnett (that brains guy)
item.description: During my undergraduate years, I had to do a brief project on aminals.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AminalBasically, if you're a tutor or lecturer who wants their students to learn to never rely on autocorrect, assign them to do the same.
